title: USB 3.0 to SATA / IDE 2.5" 3.5" HDD Hard Disk Drive Adapter

forumNotes.author: liukuohao
forumNotes.content:
Hi,

Currently, I have successfully created USB 3.0 32GB Window 7 mobile pen drive

which can be booted and run Windows 7 on itself, using my motherboad's USB 2.0 port.

But I found that the transfer speed is quite slow but still bearable.

I am wondering has anyone try this product:

[http://www.ebay.com/...=item5d39b3730f](http://www.ebay.com/itm/USB-3-0-to-SATA-IDE-2-5-3-5-HDD-Hard-Disk-Drive-Adapter-Converter-OTB-Win7-New-/400400020239?pt=US_Drive_Cables_dapters&hash=item5d39b3730f "External link")

My question is really......whether has anyone try the adapter above,

plug into motherboard that still has IDE interface............................

Next, plug in a USB 3.0 pen drive to the adapter and boot off Windows 7

via the motherboard's IDE bus. Rather than using USB 2.0 port which

I am currently using? Would this work? If it does work, then would it be

any faster?

Thanks.

Regards,

liukuohao

Or debunk it. ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif) :wink:

**No**, that thingy (like any number of similar USB 2.0 simialr boxes, quite popular) is intended to allow to (temporarily) attach an IDE (read ATA/PATA) or SATA drive to a computer USB port, see the description:

> Advance USB 3.0/2.0 adapter for converting all internal IDE drives and SATA drives into external drives.  
> Supports bi-synchronous mode for operation with both SATA and IDE device simultaneously.

the box contains an USB controller that can "drive" PATA and SATA drives.

> Or perhaps not worth of trying since the bottleneck is really the writing speed
>
> on the USB3.0 is something like 30Mb/s only, that is why I feel like it is running
>
> slow when installing programs/drivers onto the USB 3.0 pen drive (as my C drive)
>
> in Windows 7?

The bottleneck is most probably the USB 2.0 bus speed on your computer's side.

You can get a PCI to USB 3.0 card that will remove this bottleneck (and then the slower part will be your USB 3.0 stick write speed), but it depends, the PCI in itself is slowish and a PCI-e would be adviced (also post some data about your motherboard).

AND post the make/model of the stick, maybe it has been properly benchmarked and IF it is one of the "slow" ones you won't have much betterings even on a USB 3.0 connection ![:unsure:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/unsure.png).

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)

Wonko
